meanings.def: of poorer quality or lower standard; more unpleasant
examples: The rooms were awful and the food was worse.
The weather got worse during the day.
I've been to far worse places.
worse than something The film was no worse than many others he made in the 1930s.
The interview was much worse than he had expected.
The area seemed almost worse than the city he had left.
worse than doing something There's nothing worse than going out in the cold with wet hair.
worse for somebody/something It's much worse for the parents than it is for the child.

meanings.def: more serious or severe
examples: They were trying to prevent an even worse tragedy.
The crisis was getting worse and worse.
Don't tell her that—you'll only make things worse.
Could things get any worse?
Never mind—it could be worse (= although the situation is bad, it is not as bad as it might have been).
worse than (doing) something The situation was worse than he had imagined.
It's not just the government's poor ratings in the opinion polls. It's worse than that.
Killing someone is considered morally worse than letting them die.
Ignoring the problem will make it worse.
The news got dramatically worse.
The problem became progressively worse.
The problem is getting worse all the time.
Things could be a sight worse (= much worse) than they are.
Things were about to get very much worse.
We've run out of coffee. Worse still, we can't get any more until tomorrow.

meanings.def: more ill or unhappy
examples: If he gets any worse, we'll call the doctor.
worse than… He told her she'd let them down and she felt worse than ever.
She seems worse than she was yesterday.
I feel even worse today!
The pain grew worse.

meanings.def: used to say that somebody is not really as angry or as aggressive as they sound
to lose a fight, competition, etc. or suffer more compared with others
a terrible thing that could happen
examples: At the last minute the hero saves her from a fate worse than death.
Getting married seemed a fate worse than death.
Obeying her parents' wishes for her life seemed a fate worse than death.

meanings.def: to get even worse
used to show that you are disappointed about something
examples: I shall have to miss the party, worse luck!

idioms.idiom: somebody’s bark is worse than their bite
idioms.def: used to say that somebody is not really as angry or as aggressive as they sound
to lose a fight, competition, etc. or suffer more compared with others
a terrible thing that could happen
examples: At the last minute the hero saves her from a fate worse than death.
Getting married seemed a fate worse than death.
Obeying her parents' wishes for her life seemed a fate worse than death.

idioms.def: used to show that you are disappointed about something
examples: I shall have to miss the party, worse luck!

related: somebody’s bark is worse than their bite
you can/could do worse than do something

meanings.def: less well
examples: Working-class children fared rather worse.
worse than somebody/something They are performing much worse than their counterparts at competitor firms.
I didn't do it very well, but, if anything, he did it worse than I did.

meanings.def: more seriously or severely
examples: worse than somebody/something It's raining worse than ever.
He maintains that many dementia patients are treated worse than animals.

meanings.def: used to introduce a statement about something that is more serious or unpleasant than things already mentioned
examples: She'd lost her job. Even worse, she'd lost her house and her children, too.
worse than something The defeat in Parliament has undermined his authority. Worse than that, everybody's now questioning his judgement.

meanings.def: to be poorer, unhappier, etc. than before or than somebody else
examples: The increase in taxes means that we'll be £30 a month worse off than before.
I've only broken my arm; other people are far worse off than me.

meanings.def: used to say that you think something is a good idea
examples: If you want a safe investment, you could do a lot worse than put your money in a building society.

idioms.def: to be poorer, unhappier, etc. than before or than somebody else
examples: The increase in taxes means that we'll be £30 a month worse off than before.
I've only broken my arm; other people are far worse off than me.

idioms.idiom: you can/could do worse than do something
idioms.def: used to say that you think something is a good idea
examples: If you want a safe investment, you could do a lot worse than put your money in a building society.

meanings.def: more problems or bad news
examples: I'm afraid there is worse to come.
McPherson was sent off for a tackle on Mendes. Worse followed when Yardley gave Saints the lead.

meanings.def: to not be harmed by something
examples: The kids were none the worse for their adventure.

meanings.def: a person, thing, situation, etc. that is better/worse than the previous or present one
examples: Voters see the new leader as a change for the better.
I reckon we've all made a big change for the better.
His family had detected a change for the worse in his behaviour.

meanings.def: used to say that something cannot be changed, whether the result is good or bad
used to say that something is even better/worse
examples: We don't actually need it on Tuesday, but if it arrives by then, so much the better.
If hurricanes become more powerful, as current research suggests, so much the worse.

meanings.def: in a poor condition because of being used a lot
drunk
examples: He arrived home at two in the morning, much the worse for wear.
